data.title: Invoking vscode.startDebug does not invoke debugger with packaged extension
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: OS X Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an extension that calls `vscode.startDebug` with a debugger launch profile name
2. Debug the extension - observe debugger is invoked
3. Package the extension using vsce (or create symbolic link in ~/.vscode/extensions).
4. Load package using `code --install-extension`.
5. Activate extension - observe debugger is not invoked.

|---|---|---|
|read-only-indicator|alefragnani|0.4.0|
|alignment|annsk|0.3.0|
|bettertab|arenl|1.0.1|

|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|1.1.37|

|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.9.3|
|vscode-clearcase|OpenNingia|1.4.1|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|6.0.0|
|theme-cyanicpastels|SamuelLampa|0.0.9|

|change-case|wmaurer|1.0.0|
|highlight-trailing-white-spaces|ybaumes|0.0.2|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press Crtl+Shft+F.
2. Enter search term.
3. Search only in the directory (+ subdirectories if required) of the currently open file.

Available for example in SlickEdit under "Find in Files" select "<Current Buffer Directory>" in "Look in:".
Could it be handled in "files to include" by have an extra option button next to regular expressions?
Similarly would may be useful to exclude the current directory.
Could it be an extension of the regular expression syntax by having a value that expands to the current directory?

data.title: Allow custom link matchers to be registered in terminal API

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.x

Another cool feature would be to have link detection in the terminal so that users can navigate the output. Since link detection can be very specific to the command executed it might best come from the creator of a ITerminalInstance. An implementation idea would be:

- the client listens to ITerminalInstance.onData (the line based version propsed in another issue)
- marks links be line

data.title: ITerminalInstance.onData should be higher level
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.x

The callback trigger on ITerminalInstance.onData() receives a string containing the raw pty output including the ANSI Control characters. Although this might be useful for some clients I think the majority is not interested in ANSI Control characters since the interpretation is not easy. I therefore suggest that the terminal provide two different listeners. One raw listener that includes the data like it is today and one line based listener that fires if

1. a line got added to the output
1. when a line got changed. 

The event should contain the line number as well.

data.title: Show "Downloading Update" instead of "Checking for Updates..."

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It seems like VSCode is actually downloading the update while showing to user "Checking for updates". On slow connection it can take some time and it feels like VSCode just got stuck while checking if there is any update (while in fact it is downloading the update) and user might restart VSCode to see if it fixes the Update Check. Consider changing the text to `Downloading Update` if there is an update in fact and it started downloading

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/21891521/0b8de2a4-d8a1-11e6-93d2-70e0ebce0d84.png)

FYI - here is Atom:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/21891506/f7856e3a-d8a0-11e6-8ad7-e76cf70489f4.png)

data.title: 100% CPU Usage with very small project open on Ubuntu
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I am working on a project that can be found here: [Anekant-Pharma](https://github.com/ishanjain28/anekant-pharma)
2. Closed Every single thing on my PC like Plank, Spotify and Background Processes like Redis Server, Mongo Server etc. 
3. Vscode starts using 100% of 1-2 cores, Now one of these cores stays at 100% for about 30-35 seconds and other core stays at 100% for about 10-15 seconds and then both of these core go back to normal and then vscode starts using another 2 cores and this just goes on. 

Computer Information: 

i7 4710HQ 2.5Ghz, 8 Cores
8GB DDR3 RAM
1TB 5400 RPM drive

Vscode Information: 

Plugins Installed: 67
Plugins Enabled: 49

Notes: 

I am not using any of those battery saving tools like laptop-mode-tools which throttle CPU or GPU. 

My Laptop FAN starts rotating at fairly high speeds(Don't have the exact numbers, But it's faster than usual). 

I don't know how to check this, but I am certain that Vscode is probably using a lot of GPU power too. 

Normally, My Laptop gives 3 hours Backup, But I was using vscode+rhythmbox and it showed only 1 hour backup.

data.title: CALL STACK views shows path instead of name
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. debug a *.js file

Observe: the CALL STACK view doesn't show the name and line number of the file because there is not enough space:

![2017-01-12_13-21-17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/21889611/11d05f4c-d8ca-11e6-81b9-f69ac9dfd6ab.png)

If the view is resized, you can see that the full path is shown instead of the name:

![2017-01-12_13-14-11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/21889565/db22e6f4-d8c9-11e6-8881-212173d39944.png)

In the stable build only the name is shown:

![2017-01-12_13-14-54](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/21889572/e9db8bba-d8c9-11e6-935d-02ad64e79fff.png)

We should continue to show the `name` attribute of the source, not the `path`.

data.title: Setting to skip keyboard shortcut contributions of extensions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
As my list of installed extensions grows, I noticed a pattern of pain regarding keyboard shortcuts.

## From a user perspective

Every now and then a useful extension comes around with opinionated / preset shortcuts.  Generally, this is a good thing, especially for newer users that don't want to configure too much or do not have too strong feelings about their shortcuts or as an easy way to recommend a shortcut that makes sense.

As an advanced user with **very** strong own opinions what my keyboard should do I have to reconfigure a lot of them. Usually that's not a problem, setting shortcuts is straight forward. But from time to time other default VSCode shortcuts are overwritten that I want to keep, so I have to unbind the extensions default first and set my own afterwards  sometimes for multiple commands per extension.

This process bloats the settings file and raises its complexity, I'm already at 300 lines after using VSCode for only a couple of months.

## From an extension developer perspective

When building my own extensions, I am aware of my own pain point above. On one hand, I want to provide my own opinionated shortcuts and set defaults, so that new users don't have to configure them or figure out what works. After all, great user experience matters and the simple one-click-install of extensions is exactly that.

But I also don't want to pollute the settings of other advanced users. And I'm fully aware that some of my opinions only make sense with my own setup, so it is quite hard too even come up with a sane and useful default that works for everyone. Should I rather set no default shortcut at all to please the advanced user group more? Hmmm

## Proposed solution

I thought a lot about it, and the only viable solution I could come up with is introducing a setting to ignore / skip preset shortcuts from extensions. The current default behaviour (extensions can set defaults) should be kept.

## TL;DR

A setting like `"extensions.ignoreContributedKeybindings": false` solves 2 problems at once.

data.title: HTML tag autocomplete stopped working on JSX files (Code - Insiders)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.9.0-insider (1.9.0-insider) | 2017-01-11T07:05:43.066Z
- OS Version: 10.12.2

I opened this issue https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/18284 on Monday. I downloaded the nightly build to verify the fix that @aeschli introduced. It did work. 

But I found a possible regression. Autocompleting tags in `javascriptreact` files stopped working:

![new-autocomplete-issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3137417/21854150/ad01fa72-d7e7-11e6-872a-883ad66edabc.gif)

On stable it is working: 

![autocomplete-working](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3137417/21854163/c00fe6ce-d7e7-11e6-9871-41c1c3adbeb5.gif)

Thank you for the hard work guys, I'm loving VS Code.

data.title: Can't select debug target for eval in console

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: I would assume that if I pick a different debug target in the call stack, then type something in the console, it would send an evaluateRequest to the selected debug target. But when I press enter, the selection changes to the first target in the call stack, and the request is sent to the first target.
